channel.title: Comments on: .NET API for Nest Thermostat

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/index.php/archives/1449/comment-page-1#comment-20362">Spotty</a>.
Hmm. Surprised it doesn't work on WP8 (as that's supposed to be IE9, basically). Are you trying to create an WP7/8 App, or a web site that you can browse from your phone?
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Spotty.

Hmm. Surprised it doesn’t work on WP8 (as that’s supposed to be IE9, basically). Are you trying to create an WP7/8 App, or a web site that you can browse from your phone?

item.title: By: Spotty
item.dc:creator: Spotty
item.description: Got the basic connection sorted out. Not I'm trying to undertstand the part about setting the temperature.
item.content:encoded: Got the basic connection sorted out. Not I’m trying to undertstand the part about setting the temperature.

item.title: By: Spotty
item.dc:creator: Spotty
item.description:
Hi Aaron - The web site works horribly on wp7/8 (not really usable) and nest have no plans to support at the moment. I'm looking to create a simple app to turn on/off and move temp up/down. I only have a single Nest.
I've done .net development - just not much in the way of web stuff.
item.content:encoded:
Hi Aaron – The web site works horribly on wp7/8 (not really usable) and nest have no plans to support at the moment. I’m looking to create a simple app to turn on/off and move temp up/down. I only have a single Nest.

I’ve done .net development – just not much in the way of web stuff.

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Spotty.

@spotty — do you have a question/comment?

I’m guessing Nest won’t have a WP experience. Does the web site via the mobile browser work on WP7/8?

item.title: By: Spotty
item.dc:creator: Spotty
item.content:encoded:
Within the
private void btnLogin_Click(object sender, RoutedEventArgs e)

I’m trying to get some basic functionality working as Nest seem to not forthcoming with a windows phone.

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/index.php/archives/1449/comment-page-1#comment-17061">Spotty</a>.
Where are you seeing those files mentioned (I'm not seeing the reference).
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Spotty.

Where are you seeing those files mentioned (I’m not seeing the reference).

item.title: By: Spotty
item.dc:creator: Spotty
item.description: Looking at the .NET code and trying to work out what it is doing I'm curious what the nest-login1.txt and nest-status1.txt files contain as the comment says you can create one by grabbing the output of the calls but doesn't elaborate on what calls.
item.content:encoded: Looking at the .NET code and trying to work out what it is doing I’m curious what the nest-login1.txt and nest-status1.txt files contain as the comment says you can create one by grabbing the output of the calls but doesn’t elaborate on what calls.

item.title: By: Aaron
item.dc:creator: Aaron
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/blog/index.php/archives/1449/comment-page-1#comment-4888">JP</a>.
No, sorry, there's not a simple way to connect the two without more work. I've never tried it on the Mac. In theory, using Mono (.NET for Mac), it might work with some tweaks. Not sure.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to JP.

No, sorry, there’s not a simple way to connect the two without more work. I’ve never tried it on the Mac. In theory, using Mono (.NET for Mac), it might work with some tweaks. Not sure.

item.title: By: JP
item.dc:creator: JP
item.description:
These seems way out of my league as you coding geniuses have seemed to crack open the nut that I've been hoping someone would crack open. Nest is wonderful. I have a home automation system (Insteon mostly) that is aching to interface with it.
I'm not exactly sure how to run the projects listed above. I'm not a coder, though I am pretty handy around technology and not a complete idiot, but this seems to be quite complicated. I'm on a mac, so not sure if JSON even works. Downloaded something called Objectify (JSON client for mac) but it doesn't seem to want to open any of the files in your GitHub project. Please forgive my cluelessness, but any simple way to fire this up so I can send variables to my Home Auto system?
Thanks in advance for your patience.
-JP
item.content:encoded:
These seems way out of my league as you coding geniuses have seemed to crack open the nut that I’ve been hoping someone would crack open. Nest is wonderful. I have a home automation system (Insteon mostly) that is aching to interface with it.

I’m not exactly sure how to run the projects listed above. I’m not a coder, though I am pretty handy around technology and not a complete idiot, but this seems to be quite complicated. I’m on a mac, so not sure if JSON even works. Downloaded something called Objectify (JSON client for mac) but it doesn’t seem to want to open any of the files in your GitHub project. Please forgive my cluelessness, but any simple way to fire this up so I can send variables to my Home Auto system?

Thanks in advance for your patience.

-JP

item.title: By: A python API for the Nest Learning Thermostat - Dr. Scott M. Baker
item.dc:creator: A python API for the Nest Learning Thermostat - Dr. Scott M. Baker
item.description: [...] the web and came across a few other projects. One was a .net API written by Aaron at WiredPrarie (/blog/index.php/archives/1449). The other was a Siri plugin written in Ruby by Chris Burris [...]
